Rio Tinto maintains dividend Rio Tinto has used debt to deliver a 12 per cent boost to its interim dividend, despite underlying profits sliding.
PT1M6S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Rio Tinto maintains dividend as earnings beat estimates Rio Tinto's 43 per cent lower $US2.9 billion profit for the June half was better than expected, but the group is battling the law of averages as the iron ore price continues to struggle underneath the weight of production increases and soft demand.
Rio chief executive Sam Walsh pointed out on Thursday afternoon that Rio continues to make good money out of iron ore. It is producing ore at a cash cost of only $US16.20 a tonne, and at a cost of $US15.20 a tonne, taking lower energy costs and a lower Australian dollar into account.
Rio Tinto chief executive Sam Walsh in London for the company's first half earnings announcement. Photo: Julian Andrews
The iron ore division's profit before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation is still running at more than 60 cents in every dollar of sales, and Rio's iron ore production is steadily rising, offsetting price weakness to an extent.
Iron ore accounts for almost three quarters of Rio's earnings, however, and if the iron ore price doesn't recover, the second half of this year will be even tougher.
Still sliding Source: Bloomberg.
The market-Quote: d price of iron ore slid from around $US135 a tonne to about $US90 a tonne in the June half last year, and averaged $US111.79 a tonne.
In the second half of 2014 it continued to slide, hitting a low of $US66.84 two days before Christmas, and averaging $US82.54 a tonne
In the June half that Rio is now reporting on, it hit a low of $US47.08 a tonne at the beginning of April, but averaged $US60.46 a tonne.
It was $US56.78 a tonne on Thursday as Rio reported, however, and since June 30 has averaged $US52.60 a tonne - 13 per cent lower than the June half year average, and 53 per cent below the June 2014 half year average.
Walsh says that when times are dark, quality producers shine. He also says that new iron ore production is now roughly in balance with production that is being sidelined because it is unprofitable.
Weaker outlook The chances of iron ore once again super-charging Rio's profit as it did when prices were above $US100 a tonne between 2010 and the middle of last year are hugely remote, however. Predictions are perilous, but the current trend is for Rio's December half profit to be even weaker that the June half one was.
Rio has maintained its progressive dividend policy however, and the slide in the value of the Australian dollar against the US dollar is helping Rio shareholders in this country.
Rio's progressive dividend policy aims at boosting US dollar dividends over time. It pays dividends here in Australian dollars, which means they are affected by the $A-$US exchange rate.
A year ago when the Australian dollar was worth about US93¢, it declared an interim dividend of US96¢, and an Australian currency dividend of 103.1¢.
The $A was down to about US78.3¢ in February this year, when it declared a final dividend of US119¢ and an Australian dividend of just under $1.53 a share.
The new interim dividend is US107.5¢ - half the previous full-year dividend, as per the progressive dividend policy settings.
That is 11.5¢, or 12 per cent, above last year's interim payout in US dollar terms.
With the $A now down around US73¢ cents however, the $A dividend is a fraction below $1.45 - almost 41 per cent better than last year's $A interim payout.
